I've been struggling with whether to leave my meditation group because the teacher said something that really bothered me about women needing to be more submissive in practice.

That's a legitimate reason to leave. A teacher who frames submission as gendered spiritual advice is telling you something about their understanding, and it's worth taking seriously.

Some questions that might help you sort it out:

- Was this a one-time comment or part of a pattern?
- Do other students seem comfortable with it, or have others raised concerns?
- Does the teacher respond well when questioned, or does questioning get framed as resistance or ego?

If the teaching environment consistently asks you to override your own clear perception in the name of devotion, that's a structural problem, not a personality clash. Good teachers can be challenged.

If it was a one-off and the teacher is otherwise trustworthy, it might be worth raising it directly. But you're not obligated to do the work of educating your teacher. Your practice is yours.
Thank you, that really helps. I think I know what I need to do.
Good. Trust that clarity.

Can you explain the difference between shamatha and vipassana meditation?

Shamatha (calm abiding) trains stability — you place attention on an object like the breath and practice staying there. When the mind wanders, you notice and return. Over time, this builds concentration and mental calm.

Vipassana (insight) trains clear seeing — once you have some stability, you turn attention toward the nature of experience itself. You start noticing impermanence, how sensations arise and pass, how the sense of a solid self is constructed moment to moment.

In practice, they work together. Shamatha without vipassana gives you a calm mind that still operates on its usual assumptions. Vipassana without shamatha gives you insights that are too flickering to integrate. Most traditions teach some combination, though they emphasize different proportions.

The Theravada tradition tends to move from shamatha to vipassana more explicitly. Zen integrates them from the start with practices like shikantaza. Tibetan traditions often develop both in parallel.
That's really clear, thanks. I think I'll start with shamatha since I have basically no concentration ability yet.
That's a good starting point. Most teachers would agree.

I've been worrying about whether my practice is 'real' or if I'm just going through the motions.

The fact that you're noticing the difference suggests your practice isn't as hollow as you think.

"Going through the motions" is actually a normal phase. Sometimes practice is dry, mechanical, uninspired. That's not failure — it's what practice looks like when the initial enthusiasm fades and you're building the actual habit. Many long-term practitioners describe years of this before something shifted.

A few things that distinguish genuine practice from pure theater: Are you still showing up? Are you honest with yourself during practice, even when what you see isn't flattering? Do you notice, even slightly, how your mind works differently on days you sit versus days you don't?

If yes to any of those, your practice is real. It just doesn't feel like what you expected it to feel like.
That actually makes me feel a lot better. Yeah, I am showing up. I'll keep going.
That's the whole thing. Keep going.

What does 'right speech' actually mean in Buddhism? I feel like people use it to shut down any disagreement.

You're pointing at a real misuse of the concept.

Right speech in the Eightfold Path refers to speech that is truthful, not divisive, not harsh, and not idle. But notice: truthful comes first. Right speech doesn't mean "always pleasant" or "never challenging." The Buddha himself was frequently direct and sometimes blunt with students.

When "right speech" gets used to suppress legitimate disagreement, it's actually violating its own principle — because using a teaching as a silencing tool is itself a form of harmful speech. It's manipulative.

The practical test: Is the speech intended to help the other person see something clearly, even if it's uncomfortable? Or is it intended to win, punish, or inflate the speaker's sense of righteousness? That intention is the core of it.

So yes: direct feedback, honest disagreement, and naming harmful behavior can all be right speech. Weaponizing spiritual concepts to avoid accountability is not.
Okay, that's exactly what I needed to hear. I'm going to bring this up in our next group discussion.
Sounds like right speech in action. Good luck with it.

I've been thinking about impermanence a lot since my dad died last month. It used to be a concept, now it's something I actually understand.

I'm sorry about your father.

What you're describing — the shift from conceptual understanding to felt understanding — is one of the most significant transitions in practice. It's not comfortable. Intellectual impermanence is tidy. Lived impermanence is grief, and disorientation, and also a strange kind of clarity.

There's nothing I need to add to what you already know. You're in it.
Yeah. Thanks for not trying to make it into a lesson.
Of course.
